A setset is a collection of objects called the elementssetelement of a set or membersset member of a set of the set. Given an object x and a set A, exactly one of two things is true: either x is an element of A, denoted x\in Ax\in A

To denote a set that contains a small number of elements, we list the elements, separated by commas, and enclosed in curly brackets "\{\ldots\}"\{\ldots\}
curly brackets
. For example, the set A=\{x,y,z\} contains elements x,y,z, and contains no other objects. In this notation, the order in which the objects are listed does not matter. Redundancy also does not matter: the same object may be listed more than once. For example, we may write A=\{x,y,z\}=\{y,z,x\}=\{y,x,y,z\}.
Another way to denote a set is the notation \{x\colon x \text{ satisfies condition } C\}, where the colon ":" is pronounced "such that". For example, the closed unit interval of the real numbers \R is the set \{x\in \R \colon 0\leq x\leq 1\}.
The set that contains no elements is called the empty setsetthe empty set, denoted \emptyset\emptyset

We say that A is a subsetsetsubset of B, denoted A\subseteq BA \subseteq B

, if every element in the set A is also in the set B, and we write A\not\subseteq BA \not\subseteq B

to indicate that there is at least one element in A that is not an element in B. A consequence of these definitions is that if A=B, then A\subseteq B and B\subseteq A. Conversely, if A\subseteq B and B\subseteq A, then A=B. Another consequence is that the empty set is a subset of any given set A because there is no element in \emptyset that is not in A.

Instructor's solution for
The expression on the right is correct. It says the object 2 is an element of the set consisting of objects 1,2,3. The expression on the left is incorrect. The object 2 is not a subset of the set consisting of objects 1,2,3. Instead it would be correct to say \{2\}\subseteq \{1,2,3\}.
The expression on the left is correct. Since every element in the empty set is also an element of \{1,2,3\} (we say this is "vacuously true"), the empty set is a subset of \{1,2,3\}. The expression on the right is not correct. The set \{1,2,3\} has exactly three members, and the empty set is not one of them.
The last two things on the right are the same. Both symbols \emptyset and \{\} denote a set with no members. The two sets on the left are not empty: they each contain one member. But the number 0 and the empty set are not the same thing, so two sets on the left are different.

A subset R\subseteq S\times T of the product of sets S,T is called a relation from S to Trelation between sets . A relation f\subseteq S\times T is called a function from S to Tfunction if every element s in S is the left entry of exactly one element in f. We write f\colon S\to Tf\colon S\to T
a function f with domain S and codomain T
to indicate that the relation f\subseteq S\times T is a function. The set S is called the domainfunctiondomain, the set T is called the codomainfunctioncodomain, and the set f\subseteq S\times T is called the graphfunctiongraph of the function f\colon S\to T. We write f(s)=t f(s)=t
(s,t) is an element of f
to indicate that (s,t) is an element of f. If f(s)=t, we say that t is the image of s under ffunctionimage of a point and that s is a preimage of t under ffunctionpreimage of a point. Informally, we may refer to a function a process that transforms inputs (elements of the domain set) to outputs in the codomain set. When the sets S,T are understood or implied by context, it is common usage to refer to the function f\colon S\to T simply as "the function f".
To express that a relation R\subseteq S\times T consists of three parts, namely, the set S, the set T, and the subset R\subseteq S\times T, we say that a relation is a triple (S,T,R). To say that relations (S,T,R) and (S',T',R') are equal means that S=S', T=T', and R=R'. In particular, to say that two functions are equal means that they have the same domain, the same codomain, and the same graph.

Given a relation R\subseteq S\times T, the inverse relation to R inverse relation , denoted R^{-1}, is the relation from T to S given by R^{-1}=\{(t,s)\colon (s,t)\in R\}\subseteq T\times S. In general, the inverse relation f^{-1}\subseteq T\times S of a function f\colon S\to T is not a function. To say that the inverse relation f^{-1}\subseteq T\times S is a function, it must be true that every t in T is the left entry of exactly one element in f^{-1}. This is the same as saying that every t in T is the right entry of exactly one element in f, or, to say in another way, every element in the codomain of f\colon S\to T has exactly one preimage under f. In this case, f\colon S\to T is said to be invertiblefunction invertible function with inverse functionfunction inverse function f^{-1}\colon T\to S. records an important basic property of the relationship between an invertible function and its inverse function.
Let f\colon S\to T be a function, and suppose that the inverse relation f^{-1}\subseteq T\times S is a function f^{-1}\colon T\to S. Then we have f^{-1}\of f=\One_S and f\of f^{-1}=\One_T.

Let f\colon S\to T be a function, and let V,W be subsets of T. Show that f^{-1}(V\cap W)=f^{-1}(V)\cap f^{-1}(W). Do not assume that f is invertible!
To show that two sets A,B are equal, the standard method is to show that if x is an element of A, then x is also an element of B, and vice-versa. If you can do this, it then follows that A=B. Try starting this proof with: "Let x be an element of f^{-1}(V\cap W)". What can you do next? In this case, just follow the definitions. The next line is: "This means f(x) is an element of V\cap W". Now keep going!
Instructor's solution for
To say that x is an element in the set f^{-1}(V\cap W) means that f(x) is in the set V\cap W. This is the same as saying that f(x)\in V and f(x)\in W. This, in turn, is the same as saying that x\in f^{-1}(V) and x\in f^{-1}(W), which is the same as saying x\in f^{-1}(V)\cap f^{-1}(W). This chain of equivalent statements shows that f^{-1}(V\cap W)=f^{-1}(V)\cap f^{-1}(W), as desired.
